standard_metadata.standard_description: Measure volumes by counting unit cubes, using cubic cm, cubic in, cubic ft, and improvised units.

question.content: **What is the volume of the following figure?**  Front view | Back view -|-  |   is $1$ cubic unit.|   cubic units

images.alt: A 3-layer figure has the following front-view arrangement, starting from left to right: 2 cubes right at the bottom layer, 1 cube back at the bottom and middle layers, 1 cube left at the bottom, middle, and top layers.

A 3-layer figure has the following back-view arrangement, starting from left to right: 1 cube left at the bottom and middle layers, 1 cube right at the bottom, middle, and top layers, and 1 cube back at the bottom layer.
A cube has a visible front, right hand side, and top faces.

hints.content: **Volume** is the amount of space a solid figure takes up.  We can measure the volume of our figure by counting how many cubic units it takes to build the figure.   is $1$ **cubic unit** because it measures $1$ unit on every side.

images.alt: A cube has a visible front, right hand side, and top faces.  A curved bracket at the bottom edge of its front face is labeled 1 unit. A  curved bracket at the left edge of its front face is labeled 1 unit. A curved bracket at the left edge of its top face is labeled 1 unit.

hints.content: The front of the figure uses $2$ cubic units.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two cubes are in the left-right direction.

hints.content: The back of the figure uses $5$ cubic units.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt:
A 3-layer figure has the following arrangement,
starting from left to right: 3 cubes down, 1 cube right,  and 1 cube up.

hints.content: Altogether the figure uses $2+5=7$ cubic units.
The figure has a volume of $7$ cubic units.
